awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Krithika Manohar is "Selection and Regularization of Ensemble Members in Ensemble Kalman Inversion." The host institution for the fellowship is California Institute of Technology and the sponsoring scientist is Andrew Stuart.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report summarizes the outcomes of award 1803663, a Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship awarded in 2018. The funding duration for this award was September 2018 to December 2020, during which the PI conducted research in the Department of Computing and Mathematical Sciences at California Institute of Technology.

This project studied operator-theoretic machine learning models for forecasting multiscale systems in climate sciences and engineering. These techniques translate operator theory to interpretable computational methods for forecasting solely based on measured data. In the context of multiscale systems, it is common to have limited observations of slow variables while lacking faster timescale information that could be essential for accurate forecasting. The project studied the use of kernel analog forecasting to overcome the limitations posed by incomplete observations in multiscale systems exhibiting periodic, quasiperiodic, chaotic, and stochastic behavior. Kernel analog forecasts converge to future values of observables and their associated variance by advancing along the underlying but potentially unknown dynamical flow.

Significant results include long-term prediction of trajectories and forecast variance when the observed slow variables are (approximately) components of a Markov process, and numerical validation of data-driven features using operator eigenfunctions. Forecast variance closely bounds future trajectories even when missing information makes the trajectory itself hard to predict, which is useful in many applications where governing models are not available.  Subsequent research studied the design problem of which data observations to use for inverse problems on flows, akin to optimizing sensor placement in applications.

This work has had broader impacts through the PI's commitment to open science. The research findings were disseminated through publicly available online seminars. In addition, the PI developed a new graduate course on data-driven modeling and co-developed an open source software package for data-driven sensor placement. These resources not only serve as catalysts for interdisciplinary collaboration but also foster the growth of aspiring scientists. Throughout the project, the PI had the privilege of collaborating with graduate students and providing mentorship to undergraduate students.

 


Last Modified: 05/27/2023
Modified by: Krithika Manohar
